member.name: T:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Dbf.DbfReader
member.summary: Class that allows records in a dbase file to be enumerated.

member.summary: Sets or returns the date this file was last updated.

member.name: P:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Dbf.DbfReader.RecordCount
member.summary: Return the number of records in the file.
member.remarks: RecordCount is saved in DBF file as 32-bit unisigned integer. Record count is limited to 1 Billion (http://www.dbase.com/Knowledgebase/faq/dBASE_Limits_FAQ.html), so it is les than int.MaxValue

member.name: T:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shapefile
member.summary: Base shapefile class.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shapefile.MeasureMinValue
member.summary: Minimal Measure value considered as not "no-data".
member.remarks:
Any floating point number smaller than –10E38 is considered by a shapefile reader to represent a "no data" value. This rule is used only for measures (M values).
http://www.esri.com/library/whitepapers/pdfs/shapefile.pdf (page 2, bottom)

member.name: M:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shapefile.ValidateComponentSize(System.Int64)
member.summary: Validates a 2 GB size limit for any shapefile component file.

member.name: T:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapefileException
member.summary: The exception that is thrown when a non-fatal application error occurs related to Shapefile functionality.

member.name: T:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shapefiles.Readers.GeometryBuilderMode
member.summary: Specifies the geometry building algorithm to use.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shapefiles.Readers.GeometryBuilderMode.Strict
member.summary:
Shape geometry will be read assuming that it does conform to ESRI Shapefile specification. For example polygons will be created based on Shapefile's ring orientation semantics.
Ring typeOrientation
ShellClockwise, Shapefile's left-hand-rule
HoleCounter-Clockwise, Shapefile's right-hand-rule
In case of an invalid shape an error will be thrown.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shapefiles.Readers.GeometryBuilderMode.IgnoreInvalidShapes
member.summary: Shape geometry will be read assuming that it does conform to ESRI Shapefile specification. In case of an invalid shape generated geometry will be empty or will have property set to false.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shapefiles.Readers.GeometryBuilderMode.SkipInvalidShapes
member.summary: Shape geometry that does not conform to ESRI Shapefile specification will be skipped. The reader will omit the geometry and related attributes as if they didn't exist. This will result in proceding the enumeration until the end of the file is reached even if some features are corrupted (so possibly valid shapes are not ignored).

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shapefiles.Readers.GeometryBuilderMode.FixInvalidShapes
member.summary:
Invalid shape geometry will will be tried to be fixed using all possible methods. For polygons following logic will be applied:
Sort all rings.
Consider all rings as a potential shell, search the valid holes for any possible shell.
Check if the ring is inside any shell: if true, it can be considered a potential hole for the shell.
Check if the ring is inside any hole of the shell: if true, this means that is actually a shell of a distinct geometry, and NOT a valid hole for the shell. A hole inside another hole is not allowed.
member.remarks: This option is considerably slower, especially for complex geometries (i.e.: polygons with a large number of holes having large numer of vertices).

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shapefiles.Readers.GeometryBuilderMode.QuickFixInvalidShapes
member.summary:
Invalid shape geometry will will be tried to be fixed using only basic methods. For polygons following logic will be applied:
Do not sort rings but assume that polygons are serialized in the following order: Shell[, Holes][, Shell[, Holes][, ...]].
Assume that the first ring that is not contained by the current polygon is the start of a new polygon.
member.remarks: This option is is faster than but can result in geometries having property set to false.

members.member:
Well-known text representation of coordinate reference system metadata from .prj file.
https://support.esri.com/en/technical-article/000001897 />

member.name: P:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shapefiles.Readers.ShapefileReader.BoundingBox
member.summary: The Bounding Box stored in the SHP file header representing the actual extent of the shapes in the file. If the shapefile is empty (that is, has no records), the Bounding Box values are unspecified.

member.name: T:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapeType
member.summary: Shapefile geometry types.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapeType.NullShape
member.summary: Null Shape
member.remarks: Indicates a null shape, with no geometric data for the shape. Each feature type (point, line, polygon, etc.) supports nulls - it is valid to have points and null points in the same shapefile. Often null shapes are place holders - they are used during shapefile creation and are populated with geometric data soon after they are created.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapeType.Point
member.summary: Point in the X, Y space.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapeType.PolyLine
member.summary: PolyLine in the X, Y space.
member.remarks: A PolyLine is an ordered set of vertices that consists of one or more parts. A part is a connected sequence of two or more points. Parts may or may not be connected to one another. Parts may or may not intersect one another.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapeType.Polygon
member.summary: Polygon in the X, Y space.
member.remarks: A polygon consists of one or more rings. A ring is a connected sequence of four or more points that form a closed, non-self-intersecting loop. A polygon may contain multiple outer rings. The order of vertices or orientation for a ring indicates which side of the ring is the interior of the polygon. The neighborhood to the right of an observer walking along the ring in vertex order is the neighborhood inside the polygon. Vertices of rings defining holes in polygons are in a counterclockwise direction. Vertices for a single, ringed polygon are, therefore, always in clockwise order. The rings of a polygon are referred to as its parts.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapeType.MultiPoint
member.summary: MultiPoint in the X, Y space.
member.remarks: A MultiPoint represents a set of points.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapeType.PointZM
member.summary: Measured Point in the X, Y, Z space.
member.remarks: Named as PointZ in ESRI Shapefile Technical Description.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapeType.PolyLineZM
member.summary: Measured PolyLine in the X, Y, Z space.
member.remarks: Named as PolyLineZ in ESRI Shapefile Technical Description.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapeType.PolygonZM
member.summary: Measured Polygon in the X, Y, Z space.
member.remarks: Named as PolygonZ in ESRI Shapefile Technical Description.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapeType.MultiPointZM
member.summary: Measured MultiPoint in the X, Y, Z space.
member.remarks: Named as MultiPointZ in ESRI Shapefile Technical Description.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.ShapeType.PointM
member.summary: Measured Point in the X, Y space.

member.summary: Measured LineString in the X, Y space.

member.summary: Measured Polygon in the X, Y space.

member.summary: Measured MultiPoint in the X, Y space.

member.name: F:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shp.Readers.ShpReader`1.RecordNumber
member.summary:
Shapefile Spec:
The one-to-one relationship between geometry and attributes is based on record number. Attribute records in the dBASE file must be in the same order as records in the main file.
member.remarks: DBF does not have recor number attribute.

member.name: T:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shp.ShpCoordinateExtensions
member.summary: Helper methods for ordinate converting as specified in the ESRI Shapefile Technical Description.

member.name: M:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shp.ShpCoordinateExtensions.ToValidShpCoordinate(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts Z ordinate to value as specified in the ESRI Shapefile Technical Description.
member.returns:
• 0.0 if specified value is
• if specified value is
• if specified value is
otherwise it returns specified value.
member.remarks: SHP Spec: Floating point numbers must be numeric values. Positive infinity, negative infinity, and Not-a-Number(NaN) values are not allowed in shapefiles.

member.name: M:NetTopologySuite.IO.Esri.Shp.ShpCoordinateExtensions.ToValidShpMeasure(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts Measure to value as specified in the ESRI Shapefile Technical Description.
member.returns:
• value less than –10E38 if specified value is
• if specified value is
• -10E38 if specified value is
otherwise it returns specified value.
member.remarks: SHP Spec: Floating point numbers must be numeric values. Positive infinity, negative infinity, and Not-a-Number(NaN) values are not allowed in shapefiles. Nevertheless, shapefiles support the concept of "no data" values, but they are currently used only for measures. Any floating point number smaller than –10E38 is considered by a shapefile reader to represent a "no data" value.
